R.I.P   Maestro Y. Shiozawa
伊福部昭　SF特撮映画音楽の夕べ
汐澤安彦指揮　東京交響楽団
1983年8月5日　東京、日比谷公会堂　ライブ実況録音
※今年1月に急逝した指揮者、汐澤安彦による歴史的ライブ。翌年からゴジラ誕生30周年を記念して新たなゴジラシリーズが製作・開始されましたが、それに先駆け、伊福部氏が書き下ろしたSF交響ファンタジー全3部作の初演の記録です。これにより伊福部昭の音楽がゴジラ映画ファンだけでなく多くの音楽ファンに浸透することとなる記念碑的演奏であったと思います。なお最後のロンド・イン・ブーレスクは元は吹奏楽作品で、この時は管弦楽版の初演ということになります。

Title: András Schiff plays Furtwängler - Symphonic Piano Concerto (Weimar, 2001)
Description:
A happy 71st birthday to the one and only Sir András Schiff! To celebrate, here is something very special: an incredibly rare live recording of Sir András delivering a flawless performance of one of the most difficult and monumental piano concertos ever written - the Symphonic Piano Concerto by Wilhelm Furtwängler.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
Wilhelm Furtwängler - Symphonic Piano Concerto (1924-1937, rev. 1954)
► 00:00. I. Schwer, pesante
► 33:56. II. Adagio solemne
► 43:47. III. Allegro moderato
► 1:06:30. Bonus: Broadcast intro & Interview with George Alexander Albrecht
András Schiff (piano)
George Alexander Albrecht, Staatskapelle Weimar
Weimar, Weimarhalle, 11 November 2001

Title: Coleridge-Taylor - Overture to Hiawatha | Bill Eddins | New World Symphony (2023)
Description:
Among Amanda Aldridge's close relationships in the United Kingdom was one with Samuel Coleridge-Taylor, whose Hiawatha's Wedding Feast received its premiere at the Royal Albert Hall in 1898. Coleridge-Taylor would soon write sequel cantatas to Wedding Feast, establishing The Song of Hiawatha as a trilogy. In addition, he would add an overture replete with sweeping drama and crashing symbols that melt into natural majesty of Longfellow's poem. Born in Britain, Coleridge-Taylor reached back to the United States for inspiration—Longfellow was the inspiration, and the Overture contains reference to "Nobody Knows the Trouble I've Seen." Hiawatha was so well received, in fact, that from 1927 to 1939 received an annual performance at Royal Albert.

—James Bennett II

Originally performed February 4, 2023.
  
 #hiawatha #overture #symphony #orchestra

Title: Concerto for Brass Sextet and Wind Orchestra (1994) — Derek Bourgeois
Description:
From 1971 to 1984, Derek Bourgeois was a lecturer in music at Bristol University, and director of the National Youth Orchestra from 1984 to 1993. In 1980 he began conducting the Sun Life Band (now the Stanshawe Band of Bristol), which was his introduction to brass bands. In 1994 Bourgeois was appointed Director of Music at St Paul's Girls School, London, a position previously held by a number of noted composers, including Gustav Holst and Herbert Howells.

COMPOSER: Derek Bourgeois
CONDUCTOR: Peter Snellinckx
BRASS: Members of the Belgian Navy Band
BAND: Belgian Navy Band

TRACKLIST:
0:00 - I.
8:22 - II.
13:58 - III.

I upload these solely for archiving purposes, and for the sharing and enjoyment of great music. Monetization is not enabled. Title: Ilmari Hannikainen - Concerto for piano and orchestra Op. 7 (audio + sheet music)
Description:
Toivo Ilmari Hannikainen (19 October 1892 – 25 July 1955) was a Finnish composer and virtuoso pianist.

Hannikainen was the son of Pekka Juhani Hannikainen and the brother of Väinö Hannikainen, both of whom were composers and of Tauno Hannikainen who was a cellist and conductor. After studying at the University of Helsinki (1911–14), he became a pupil of Franz Schreker at the Musikakademie in Vienna, and continued his studies with Alexander Siloti in Saint Petersburg (1915–17) and with Alfred Cortot in Paris (1919). Returning to Finland, he taught piano at the Helsinki Conservatory and later gained a Professorship at the Sibelius Academy.

Hannikainen steered Finnish classical music from late Romanticism towards Impressionism. In addition to his piano miniatures, which best illustrated this development, he composed one opera, one piano concerto, one piano quartet, lieder, and film scores (notably, the 1934 Swedish film Sången om den eldröda blomman).

Hannikainen drowned during a sailing trip in Kuhmoinen in 1955. Some musical colleagues, like Aarre Merikanto, considered his death a suicide. He is buried in the Hietaniemi Cemetery in Helsinki.

In the 1970s, the Ilmari Hannikainen Pianokilpailu (Ilmari Hannikainen Piano Competition) was created dedicated to Hannikainen. In 2020, the competition renewed its format style.

(Wikipedia)

Please take note that the audio AND sheet music ARE NOT mine. Feel free to change the video quality to a minimum of 480p for the best watching experience.

Original audio: 
Arto Satukangas (piano), Finnish Radio Symphony Orchestra (cond. Petri Sakari)
(https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=J-HOwvjU6Xw)

Title: Mendelssohn Symphony No 3 “Scottish” SF Symphony, de Waart 1985
Description:
Edo de Waart conducts the San Francisco Symphony in performance of Felix Mendelssohn’s Symphony No 3 “Scottish” on Jan 31, 1985.

Technical Info:
Scotch 226, quarter track stereo
10.5” reel
3 3/4 IPS
Scotch 226 suffers from “Sticky Shed Syndrome” and requires special preparation before it can be played. Unfortunately that means there can be occasional dropouts or fades - you can hear some of that in this recording. Luckily the majority of the piece is intact. More details about the preparation I took on the reel:
https://www.youtube.com/post/Ugkxh8TfxsulklceOY2PnuGTzfKIjI7Wvxiv

Title: Schubert (Weingartner): Symphony No. 7.  Berlin Radio Symphony Orchestra (1979)
Description:
This symphony, now generally designated as Schubert's Symphony No. 7, was started by Schubert but was not completed by him. At least three completions of the symphony have been made. The version being played here was completed by the Austrian composer Felix Weingartner in 1934.

This recording and this release (Spectrum) appears to be relatively scarce, as Discogs.com lists only 2 collections that hold it.   The more common release (but still scarce) was issued in 1978 by the East German label Eterna.  This is an excellent performance and the recording is of higher quality than most East European labels of the time.  (The record itself was made in the Netetherlands.

Tracks/Movements:
00:00    Adagio - Allegro
11:44    Andante
19:40    Scherzo (Allegro)
26:47    Allegro giusto

Details:
Album title:  Franz Schubert:  Symphony No.7
Released by:  Spectrum (S-116)
Year released: 1979
Orchestra:  Radio Symphony Orchestra of Berlin
Conductor:  Heinz Roegner

Title: Schuman Circus Overture - Mitropoulos Minneapolis Symphony 1949
Description:
In the final months of his tenure as conductor of the Minneapolis Symphony, Dimitri Mitropoulos leads the MSO in performance of William Schuman’s Circus Overture on January 20th, 1949. An exciting modern piece with really poignant brass and percussion parts. Perfect to keep the attention of a bunch of Minneapolis-area children as this was a Children’s Concert. As you can tell from this really outstanding sounding recording Mitropoulos brought as much energy and artistry to the youth concerts as he did the main symphony performances. 

This particular piece had its Minneapolis Symphony debut a few weeks earlier on Friday January 7th. In that performance the featured piano player was Arturo Michelangeli. I’m pretty sure that is not who was playing the piano parts in this recording. Mitropoulos was an accomplished piano player - perhaps at this children’s concert he’s playing the sparse piano parts himself? 

What’s interesting is that the most well known arrangement for this is for concert band, which typically would not have a piano. But, if you seek out the original (not concert band) score there is indeed a part for piano. 


Technical Info:
Unknown Scotch tape type
7” reel
15 IPS
For 1949, I am super blown away at the high quality of this recording. It’s one of my best and certainly the best sounding from the 1940s. As I’ve mentioned on this channel several times before Mr. Marchant worked for 3M and was using experimental tape formulations with his recordings to tweak the product 3M was making. This tape is an ochre/red color and using the official list of released 3M tape I don’t see that color all the way until 1954 with Scotch 150. Given the very old look of the box I seriously doubt it is 150, but perhaps an early version of it was being tried all the way back in 1949.

Title: Slatkin & St. Louis Symphony: Schumann’s 4th in D Minor (1841 Version) 1982
Description:
Leonard Slatkin conducts the St. Louis Symphony in performance of Robert Schumann’s Symphony no. 4. The date I have on the tape is written as “recorded live 8/19/1982” - which I assume is off of the radio with some sort of radio broadcast or simulcast. Of note - this is a performance of the original 1841 version, not the one later revised in 1851. 

Welcome to a new type of video from the Marchant Archives - glorious stereo and much higher quality! I have mostly (but not 100%) gotten through the older tapes from the 1940s and 1950s that are in the “half track” format that was dominant in the early days of taping. Now I am looking through more modern reels from the 60s, 70s, and 80s. Many of these were recorded by Mr. Marchant’s daughter (the one I inherited the collection from). These were recorded in the “quarter track” format which means they will almost always be stereo. It also means a different tape deck so the videos might look slightly different. 

While I know this is not a lost Mitropoulos performance from 1947 I hope you’ll still enjoy it. Let me know what you think! And if anyone knows more about what performance this would have been please let me know. It's clearly live since you hear an audience but I couldn’t find any St. Louis Symphony archives to search through. He did some guest conducting with the SF Symphony around this period, but that was apparently only Beethoven and the performances were in June.

Finally - the chapter markers I’ve added are using the Italian tempo notations instead of German, as that is what Schumann used on the 1841 version.

Technical Info:
Scotch Dynarange 7R
7” reel
3 3/4 IPS
3 3/4 inches per second is generally the lowest speed on most musical magnetic audio recordings. It is useful because it means you can record for a lot longer, but generally the higher the speed (like 7 1/2 or 15 IPS) the better the quality. Luckily with this reel that’s not the case as it sounds fantastic. 

00:00 - Andante con moto
09:03 - Romanza: Andante
13:29 - Scherzo: Presto
19:03 - Largo — Finale: Allegro vivace
26:02 - Radio announcer wrap-up

Title: Uljas Pulkkis: Tears of Ludovico [w/ score] (1998)
Description:
Uljas Pulkkis (*1975)
Tears of Ludovico, for pianoforte solo and symphony orchestra (1998)

Shai Wosner, piano
Belgian National Orchestra
Marc Soustrot, conductor


Thomas Ludovico de Victoria is a Spanish composer who lived from 1548 to 1611. He only wrote around sixty works, but was held in great esteem and his compositions were very popular. The most well-known of his works are Officum Hebdomadae Sanctae (Tenebrae, 1585) and Officum defunctorum (Requiem, 1605, last work). These two compositions are sombre, empassioned and full of anxiety, like most of his late works. Victoria lived in an easy and superficial way, but consecrated his tears to masses and motets, which have retained moving quality up to the present day.

When I heard Victoria's music at the first time, I was deeply moved. It was the most beautiful music I had ever heard, and still is. For that I would like to honour the memory of this great composer. The name Tears of Ludovico refers to the late works of Victoria, with which my composition shares the main musical characteristics: darkness, passion and anguish.


© Finnish Music Information Centre

Full Score
https://cutt.ly/UP_tears-of-ludovico

Official Composer Website
https://uljaspulkkis.com/


This video has a purpose of promotion, not for profit.
If you have any complaints about copyright issues, please write me a direct message at dhdmlwls02(at)gmail(dot)com before submitting a report to YouTube. Then I will delete the video as soon as possible.

Title: Viktoria Postnikova plays Strauss Burleske - video 1989
Description:
Viktoria Postnikova playing Richard Strauss's Burleske with the State Academic SO under Gennady Rozhdestvensky, live in Moscow in 1989. Skip to 00:47 for the start. Postnikova studied with Yakov Flier. She shared second at the 1966 Leeds competition, shared first at the 1968 Vianna da Motta competition, and shared third at the 1970 Tchaikovsky competition.

Виктория Постникова - Рихард Штраус - Бурлеска для фортепиано с оркестром - Геннадий Рождественский - Burlesque
